title: Supplement for Interim Analysis and Multiple Testing Strategy in TEMPLATE Study
text: 20-month accrual period, total sample size planned study 500.

title: Supplement for Interim Analysis and Multiple Testing Strategy in TEMPLATE Study
text: multiplicity strategy follows graphical approach group sequential designs Maurer Bretz (2013) provides strong control type 1 error. procedure takes account sources multiplicity: multiple hypothesis tests (e.g., across primary secondary endpoints) multiple analyses planned study (.e., interim final analyses). two key components define approach Testing algorithm multiple hypotheses specified graphical representation Repeated testing hypotheses using alpha-spending function methodology multiplicity strategy applied 2 primary superiority hypotheses ( PFS B+ PFS ) 2 key secondary superiority hypotheses ( ORR PRO ). Table @ref(tab:inputTable) summarizes hypotheses specifying alpha-spending functions (hypotheses tested group sequentially) together effect sizes planned maximum statistical information (sample size number events). Summary Primary Key Secondary Hypotheses Figure @ref(fig:timelinePlot) provides details statistical information projected available (percentage relative maximum) versus time since trial start endpoint types. vertical lines figure mark times interim analyses. overall type family-wise error rate 4 hypotheses, (interim final) analyses, controlled 2.5% (one-sided). Figure @ref(fig:MTgraph) shows graph hypotheses interest represented elliptical nodes. node hypothesis weight assigned (denoted ww). particular value ww sets local significance level associated hypothesis (equal 0.025ww). graphical approach allows local significance levels recycled (along arrows graph) given hypothesis successful (.e., corresponding null hypothesis rejected) interim final analyses. arrow specifies fraction ww (number attached ) transferred source node destination node. ‚Äúalpha-propagation‚Äù results corresponding increase local significance level destination node. Figure @ref(fig:MTgraph) defines initial configuration local significance levels directed edges (arrows). Particularly, initial weight assignment PFS BM+ set 1, respectively. Graph Depicting Multiple Hypothesis Testing Strategy. testing algorithm codes series graph transformations happens successful clearing hypothesis described Maurer Bretz (2013). execution procedure, different scenarios local significance levels emerge iterative manner.

title: Supplement for Interim Analysis and Multiple Testing Strategy in TEMPLATE Study
text: IA Hypothesis IA Calendar Time Enrollment Data Availability Plot Table @ref(tab:iaDetailsTableA) @ref(tab:iaDetailsTableB) summarize planned interim analyses. Summary Interim Analyses (hypotheses) Summary Interim Analyses (calendar analysis) Timelines.

title: Supplement for Interim Analysis and Multiple Testing Strategy in TEMPLATE Study
text: Scenarios Bounderies Power Spending Functions hypothesis, Table @ref(tab:graphTable) gives possible scenarios local significance levels first column, corresponding ww second column, listing scenarios hypothesis testing needs successful third column. List possible local alpha levels following graphical testing procedure Table @ref(tab:grSeqTable) details procedure regarding hypothesis testing interim final analyses. given hypothesis group sequential testing planned, table provides nominal p-value boundary derived given alpha-spending function information fractions. boundary compared observed p-values calculated test statistics corresponding analyses. timing analyses expressed terms statistical information fractions, .e., current analysis information relative total plan information hypothesis test. Also, table reports power (cumulatively analyses) assuming hypotheses‚Äô effect sizes Table @ref(tab:inputTable). Efficacy p-value Boundaries Figure @ref(fig:plotSF) visualizes alpha-spending functions profiled local significance levels available hypotheses describing potential scenarios needed execution multiple testing procedure. Alpha-spending functions

title: Supplement for Interim Analysis and Multiple Testing Strategy in TEMPLATE Study
text: Maurer W, Bretz F. Multiple testing group sequential trials using graphical approaches. Statistics Biopharmaceutical Research. 2013;5(4):311-320.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Yevgen Tymofyeyev. Author, maintainer. Michael Grayling. Author.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Tymofyeyev Y, Grayling M (2025). appendMCP: Tools defining graphical multiple testing procedures group sequential design studies. R package version 0.1.0.
code: @Manual{,   title = {appendMCP: Tools for defining graphical multiple testing procedures in group sequential design studies},   author = {Yevgen Tymofyeyev and Michael Grayling},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0}, }

what: Tools for defining graphical multiple testing procedures in group sequential design studies
title: Tools for defining graphical multiple testing procedures in group sequential design studies
text: goal appendMCP provide routines describing graphical multiple comparison procedures (MCPs) group sequential design (GSD) studies. primary objective generate R Markdown file defines testing procedure interim analyses, can appended statistical analysis plan (SAP) document. package includes predefined templates users can customize, ideally modifying small set high-level input parameters.

title: Tools for defining graphical multiple testing procedures in group sequential design studies
text: can install development version appendMCP GitHub :

title: Tools for defining graphical multiple testing procedures in group sequential design studies
text: load template RStudio, go File ‚Üí\rightarrowNew File ‚Üí\rightarrowR Markdown ‚Ä¶ , select Template (left panel), choose ‚ÄúMCP GSD‚Äù list. can also load template command line: , can knit R Markdown file generate report. (library(appendMCP) called automatically within file). report describes trial design assumptions, interim analyses, hypothesis testing, relevant information.
code: # install.packages("rmarkdown") rmarkdown::draft("my_report", template = "mcpgen", package = "appendMCP")  # To open created file in Rstudio editor use rstudioapi::navigateToFile("my_report/my_report.Rmd")

title: Tools for defining graphical multiple testing procedures in group sequential design studies
text: can view rendered example R Markdown template following vignette: üëâ Example Report appendMCP Template

what: Reporting graphical comparison procedures in GSD studies ‚Äî appendMCP
title: Reporting graphical comparison procedures in GSD studies ‚Äî appendMCP
text: appendMCP provides routines describing graphical multiple comparison procedures (MCP) group sequential design (GSD) studies. objective generate R Markdown file defines MTP interim analyses, can appended statistical analysis plan document.

title: Reporting graphical comparison procedures in GSD studies ‚Äî appendMCP
text: package provides predefined templates can modified user, ideally changing high-level input parameters. load template Rstudio, use "File" -> "New File" -> "R Markdown ..." Select "Template" (left panel), choose "MCP GSD"

title: Reporting graphical comparison procedures in GSD studies ‚Äî appendMCP
text: Maintainer: Yevgen Tymofyeyev ytymofye@.jnj.com Authors: Michael Grayling mgraylin@.jnj.com

code: # Load template from command line: # rmarkdown::draft("my_report", template = "mcpgen", package = "appendMCP", edit = FALSE) # To open created file in Rstudio editor use # rstudioapi::navigateToFile("my_report/my_report.Rmd")

title: appendMCP internal S3 ‚Äî getDelta
text: Obtain parameter H1 natural scale Format string reporting effect Compute standardization factor, psi, links natural parameter effect size, theta Obtain calendar time given sample size (events) Calculate sample size (number events) available  given calendar time

title: appendMCP internal S3 ‚Äî getDelta
code: getDelta(x)  # Default S3 method getDelta(x)  # S3 method for class 'tte_exp' getDelta(x)  getEffectSizeDetails(x)  # S3 method for class 'normal' getEffectSizeDetails(x)  # S3 method for class 'binomial' getEffectSizeDetails(x)  # S3 method for class 'binomial_pooled' getEffectSizeDetails(x)  # S3 method for class 'binomial_unpooled' getEffectSizeDetails(x)  # S3 method for class 'tte_exp' getEffectSizeDetails(x)  getStandardizingCoef(x, ratio = 1)  # Default S3 method getStandardizingCoef(x, ratio = 1)  # S3 method for class 'binomial' getStandardizingCoef(x, ratio = 1)  # S3 method for class 'binomial_pooled' getStandardizingCoef(x, ratio = 1)  # S3 method for class 'binomial_unpooled' getStandardizingCoef(x, ratio = 1)  n2Time(x, n, enrollment, ratio)  # Default S3 method n2Time(x, n, enrollment, ratio = 1)  # S3 method for class 'tte_exp' n2Time(x, n, enrollment, ratio = 1)  Time2n(x, T, enrollment, ratio)  # Default S3 method Time2n(x, T, enrollment, ratio = 1)  # S3 method for class 'tte_exp' Time2n(x, T, enrollment, ratio = 1)

title: appendMCP internal S3 ‚Äî getDelta
text: x endpoint object ratio Allocation ratio n sample size number events enrollment Enrollment object T Calendar time points

title: appendMCP internal S3 ‚Äî getDelta
code: if (FALSE) { # Internally dispatched examples (for development or internal tests) getStandardizingCoef(list(list(), class = "tte_exp"), ratio = 1) # should return 0.5 }
